I am going to make chicha today.{''}'\footnote{In Rondônia, this is usually a lightly alcoholic drink based on boiled fermented maize, manioc or yams, which is prepared by women. Elsewhere it is also known as kashiri or caxiri.},\footnote{The form deri is a false start: the narrator begins to say derinena `at daybreak' (lit. `light-pfv-ds') but then corrects himself, saying zãme `today'.}

trs: But now they were behaving well again.

html:

shaman
tãwĩ-kuka-pü
await-clf:body-ss
irü-pü
trance-ss
label: hadite tãwĩ-kuka-pü irü-pü
trs: He called the shaman to enter into a trance.'\footnote{In this state the shaman is sitting down on his/her bench while pulling down the invisible lines that form the net on which his/her spirit can travel, the haditaezũ daruma `shaman's sling'. In order to heal, he/she performs acts such as sucking, blowing smoke, gestures of collecting, extracting, expelling, etc. The last Aikanã shaman passed away in 1985, but elderly people remember the tradition and are often able to interpret the work of shamans from other ethnic groups.}

html:
wãwã'ĩ
child
uki-ke-kuka-ku-'ẽ
clean-3-clf:body-1sg.ben-imp
awexü
demon
urume-ẽ
transform-decl
label: wãwã'ĩ uki-ke-kuka-ku-'ẽ awexü urume-ẽ
trs: ``Cleanse the body of my daughter, who has transformed into a demon!{''}'\footnote{The awexü is a dangerous and powerful spirit of the forest that can transform itself into any being and is able to make people lose their mind. Especially when someone is alone in the forest or on a remote cultivated plot, the awexü may trick someone and lead him/her astray or directly attack and kill a person. Unexpected death and psychotic illness are often explained as the work of the awexü. Experiences with the awexü are always traumatic and accounts of them are harrowing.}
